column4: I apologize for repeating questions but I've pined through hundreds of threads on the ubuntu forums/docs and I just can't find anything on this. I can get ulimit -n to work fine in a shell (https://gist.github.com/7fff364c0bca20c27aa5), but never to hold a value for an upstart process. Does anybody know how to set the ulimit values for processes that are not spawned in a bash shell?
I have no idea if it addresses your question, but have you checked the upstart cookbook?
there's a #upstart here on freenode that may be able to help
Ubuntu appears not to be honoring my /etc/default/ubuntu values, but I have no idea why.
Thanks, I'll ask there. I don't think it's an upstart issue though.
how are you setting the ulimit?
I've tried a few things. Set high system limits in /etc/security/limits.conf. Tried making a /etc/default/ubuntu that set it. Also tried setting it directly in the upstart file.
did you see if it made a difference whether the service starts at boot or later on?  (So for example stop the service and then start it again after the boot process is over)
Yes, it fails in both cases.
there's some discussion here http://serverfault.com/questions/195655/squid-running-out-of-file-descriptors-on-ubuntu though the user is on 10.04
maybe give more details about what you are doing if you can
May have found the solution here: http://upstart.ubuntu.com/wiki/Stanzas#limit It looks like upstart has its own way of doing limits; oddly unmentioned in any of the upstart tutorials i saw
I appreciate the help, think I'm close enough to get the rest of the way on my own
